story.text: NEW YORK Jan 2 Progress Energy Inc.'s (PGN.N) 937-megawatt Brunswick 2 nuclear power station in North Carolina was at 80 percent power early Tuesday after exiting a brief outage, the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission said in a power plant status report. The unit, in Southport, North Carolina, about 160 miles south of Raleigh, shut for work a little over a week ago following an automatic trip of the plant. Meanwhile, the adjacent 938-MW Unit 1 continued to run at full power on Tuesday, according to the NRC report. Separately, the NRC in June renewed the operating licenses for both units for another 20 years. The licenses for Units 1 and 2 will now expire in 2036 and 2034, respectively. One MW powers about 700 homes in North Carolina. Progress Energy operates the station for its owners, Progress (81.7 percent) and North Carolina Eastern Municipal Power Agency (18.3 percent). Progress Energy owns and operates more than 24,000 MW of generating capacity, markets energy commodities, and transmits and distributes electricity to about 2.9 million customers in North Carolina, South Carolina and Florida.
story.title: progress ' nc brunswick 2 reactor up to 80 pct power
